attributes.title: Individual differences in perceptual capacity and multisensory inattentional unawareness

q1.value: Individual differences in perceptual capacity and multisensory inattentional unawareness

q2.value: Magdalena del Rio, Jamie Ward, Chloe Dennis, Caitlin Jarman-Hume, Samuel Mckay

q3.value:
People with high sensory sensitivity can find everyday lights, sounds and smells to be particularly aversive and/or overwhelming. These experiences can occur within the general population, although they are more prevalent in certain groups, such as autism spectrum conditions (Robertson & Simmons, 2013). In addition to a more intense subjective experience of sensory sensitivity, there is evidence of what might be described as increased behavioral sensory sensitivity (Mottron et al, 2006). Specifically, autisitic individuals show increased processing of irrelevant peripheral information to no detriment in their performance in the central task, both in the visual (e.g. Swettenham et al, 2014), and in the auditory domain (Remington & Fairnie, 2017). It has hence been suggested that autistic individuals have an enhanced perceptual capacity which could underlie both advantages in these types of tasks and the sensory issues (Remington & Fairne, 2017). However, the association between these individual differences in behavioral tasks and the individual’s traits, especially relating to sensory issues, has, to the best of our knowledge, not been tested yet.
In this study, we will investigate individual differences in perceptual capacity using a subitizing task (Eayrs & Lavie, 2018) as well as inattentional blindness (e.g. Cartwright-Finch & Lavie, 2006), deafness  (Dalton & Fraenkel, 2012) and anosmia paradigms (Forster & Spence, 2018).

q4.value: We hypothesize that 1) self-reported sensory sensitivity as measured by the Glasgow Sensory Questionnaire, (GSQ; Robertson & Simmons, 2013) will positively correlate with a) perceptual capacity as indexed by the subitizing threshold and b) the likelihood to detect unattended stimuli, irrespective of sensory modality, 2) self-reported autistic traits as measured by the Autism Quotient, (AQ; Baron-Cohen et al, 2001)  will positively correlate with the likelihood to detect unattended stimuli, irrespective of sensory modality, 3) the likelihood to detect unattended stimuli, irrespective of sensory modality, will correlate with the perceptual capacity as indexed by the subitizing threshold.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Mixed design study (within-subject as well as between-subjects comparisons) in a study comprising 5 behavioral experiments and 2 questionnaires. The order of the two computer-based behavioral experiments will be counterbalanced by generating a look-up table in advance, which will assign a random order to each participant number. No further counterbalancing of the order will be possible due to the nature of the experiments: unattended auditory and olfactory stimuli will be presented throughout the testing session, and the critical stimulus in the inattentional blindness experiment will be presented at the end of the subitizing experiment to avoid any interference with the subitizing task.

q9.value:
-Questionnaires: The order of the questions in the AQ and GSQ is randomized.

- Subitizing: There will be 9 conditions corresponding to the set size, i.e. number of items (1 to 9) on the screen. The task will comprise 3 slow practice trials, 6 practice trials at the actual speed of the experiment, and 3 experimental blocks of 54 trials each (6 repetitions of each of the 9 conditions per block). The order of the conditions will be randomized within each block, including the practice blocks. The items will be black squares, randomly positioned in an area subtending 7.15° x 7.15°, randomly ranging in size between 0.38° x 0.38° and 3.8° x 3.8°.

- Inattentional blindness: The critical stimulus will be presented on two additional trials at the end of the subitizing task. The first of these consitutes the inattentional blindness trial, and the second is a control trial. Participants will not receive any instruction or indication prior to the first trial, but will be instructed to "Now ignore the squares - do not indicate the number of squares on the screen. Instead, look for anything additional on the display" before the control trial to ensure participants are capable of detecting the stimulus under low load conditions. The critical stimulus is an asterisk, randomly positioned to the left or right of the set of squares (thus counterbalanced across participants), at a constant eccentricity from the fixation cross. To ensure a consistently high load, these two trials will have a fixed set size of 6 for all participants. The location of the critical stimulus will be the same in the control trial, to maintain all conditions but attention constant. These trials will not be used in the analysis of the subitizing task. Participants will be asked if they detected the critical stimulus and to indicate the location and identity of the stimulus after each of the two trials. The possible responses to the location and identification questions will appear in a randomly permuted order.

The remaining tasks consist of single main measures (constant across participants) and do not require randomisation.  These are two inattentional deafness tasks (noticing the presence of the word “gorilla” in an unattended audio stream and noticing the ambient presence of a ticking clock throughout the experiment) and inattentional anosmia (noticing the ambient aroma of coffee throughout the experiment).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
A small set of pilot data (N=13) was collected for debugging purposes and to ensure that stimuli are presented at appropriate intensity levels (such that fewer than 50% of participants notice them). This data was not analysed in relation to the hypotheses. As this study is being conducted as part of three students' undergraduate projects at the University of Sussex and the stimuli did not need adjustment, the pilot data may be used by the students due to time constraints in the data collection process, but it will not be included in any publication.
Participants may have already completed the questionnaires as part of a previous study. If so, we will use this existing questionnaire data, and only require participants to complete the behavioral experiments.

question.value: Participants will be recruited through advertisements at the University of Sussex. They will be at least 18 years old and will report normal or corrected-to-normal vision and hearing. As compensation for their time we will conduct a prize draw, with three prizes of £25.  If the sample size is not reached at the end of the student testing period, we will offer compensation at the rate of £8 or 4 credits per hour.

q13.value:
We will collect a minimum of 150 complete data sets (i.e. participants who complete all 5 of the tasks and both questionnaires), and a maximum of 200 complete data sets, with an additional cap on the total number of participants of 220, irrespective of missing or excluded data.
We will additionally calculate Bayes factors (BF) after the minimum sample size has been collected and in batches of 20 participants thereafter. If all BFs on the following tests fall either below or above the standard threshold of ⅓ or 3 respectively, we will stop data collection: correlation between the subitizing capacity and the percentage of detected unattended stimuli, correlation between GSQ and the subitizing capacity, correlation between AQ and the subitizing capacity, correlation between GSQ and the percentage of detected unattended stimuli, correlation between AQ and the percentage of detected unattended stimuli.

q14.value:
A power analysis was performed using the software program  G*Power (Erdfelder et al, 1996), for each planned test.

-Within-subject correlation between perceptual capacity and inattentional unawareness
Prior effect sizes have been noted for inattentional blindness but not other sensory modalities. Assuming similar effect sizes will apply for all sensory modalities, we used the correlations found by Eayrs & Lavie, 2018, which ranged between rs=0.27 and rs=0.39, as our prior estimate. (This paper reported results for 3 separate studies which included change blindness or load-induced blindness tasks alongside the subitizing task in each. Performance in the change blindness and load-induced blindness tasks was quantified using detection sensitivity and detection rate, yielding a number of correlations within the range specified above.)  Using the upper and lower bounds of the reported effect size as a prior, a power analysis revealed that a sample size of n=46-102 should be sufficient to detect an effect size of this magnitude with a power of .8, assuming a significance level of .05 when performing a correlation or linear regression with a single predictor and regression coefficient (two-tailed test). 

- Across subjects: association between inattentional unawareness and GSQ/AQ
The GSQ questionnaire has only been used in one similar study (a previous student project at the University of Sussex) in which participants were divided into aware and unaware groups based on an inattentional blindness stimulus (a non-alphanumeric character presented in an unattended location during a visual search task).  Given our working assumption that the phenomenon is multi-modal, we apply the inattentional blindness effect size to inattentional deafness and inattentional anosmia (where prior effect sizes are unavailable). This study found a medium effect size (Cohen’s d of 0.5) of awareness on GSQ, which we used as our prior estimate - this would correspond to a Cohen’s f of 0.25  and hence a Cohen’s f^2 of 0.0625 (a medium effect size for multiple regression and F tests). A power analysis revealed that a sample size of n=129 should be sufficient to detect an effect size of this magnitude with a power of .8, assuming a significance level of .05 when performing multiple linear regression or correlation (two-tailed test).
For the association between inattentional unawareness and AQ, we relied on data comparing neurotypical participants to participants diagnosed with autism spectrum conditions (Remington et al, 2012; Remington & Fairnie, 2018). As the effect size calculated based on the reported results in high-load conditions is high in the visual modality (Cohen’s d of 0.88), and medium in the auditory modality (Cohen’s d of 0.4), we based our power analysis calculation on the smaller effect size. A power analysis revealed that a sample size of  n=199 should be sufficient to detect an effect size of this magnitude with a power of .8, assuming a significance level of .05 when performing multiple linear regression or correlation (two-tailed test).

- Across subjects: association between subitizing capacity and GSQ/AQ
Studies comparing neurotypical individuals and individuals with autism spectrum conditions (ASC) report either small negative effects or no effect of ASCs on subitizing capacity (Jarrold & Russell, 1997; Gagnon et al, 2004; O’Hearn et al, 2013; O’Hearn et al, 2015). However, it should be noted that a number of these studies include children and all focus on clinically diagnosed ASCs. Furthermore, Eayrs & Lavie, 2018, show that subitizing predicted change detection rates and the performance of both tasks were underpinned by a single factor according to their confirmatory factor analysis, and there is evidence of reduced susceptibility to change blindness in autism (e.g. Swettenham et al, 2014; Smith & Milne, 2009). Given the conflicting accounts for the relationship of subitizing and AQ, we do not have a prediction regarding the effect of AQ on the subitizing threshold (this part of the analysis could therefore be considered exploratory, but is detailed here for legibility.) 
In the absence of empirical evidence on any association between the GSQ and subitizing, we assume similar effect sizes for the association between subitizing capacity and GSQ as we did for the association between inattentional unawareness and GSQ.

q15.value:
As the main area of interest is the association of the GSQ with the performance on these behavioral tasks, we will collect a minimum of 150 complete data sets (i.e. participants who complete all 5 of the tasks and both questionnaires),  and a maximum of 200 complete data sets, with an additional cap on the total number of participants of 220, irrespective of missing or excluded data.
We will additionally begin calculating BFs after every additional 20 participants once we reach the minimum sample size. If all BFs on the following tests are either below or above the threshold of ⅓ or 3, as specified above, we will stop data collection: correlation between the subitizing capacity and the percentage of detected stimuli, correlation between GSQ and the subitizing capacity, correlation between GSQ and the percentage of detected stimuli, correlation between AQ and the percentage of detected stimuli.

question.value:
- Subitizing task: We manipulated the set size, i.e. number of squares on the display. The 9 levels of this variable are set sizes from 1 to 9.

- Inattentional blindness: We manipulated the location of the critical stimulus on the screen. The two levels of this variable are left and right. We also manipulated the load/attention. The two levels of this variable are a high load condition with no warning regarding the critical stimulus, and a low load condition with an instruction to not perform the task and instead look for any additional stimuli on the screen.

- Inattentional deafness (gorilla task): We manipulated load/attention while playing an identical recording of an auditory scene with an auditory critical stimulus (Dalton & Fraenkel, 2012) . The two levels of this variable are "attend to female voices" and "attend to male voices". If the critical stimulus is detected in the "attend to female voices" condition, the second condition will be omitted.

- Inattentional deafness: We manipulated the auditory environment by playing the sound of a ticking clock at a constant intensity for all participants throughout the experiment. We also manipulated the context in which the participants were prompted to indicate any unusual stimuli and the explicitness of the prompts (5 levels of this variable: free response out of the room, response to a sensory modality specific prompt out of the room, free response in the room, response to a sensory modality specific prompt in the room, response to a stimulus  specific prompt in the room).  If the critical stimulus is detected, the following prompts will be omitted.

- Inattentional anosmia: We manipulated the olfactory environment by keeping coffee fragrance oil in the room, ensuring similar intensity of a coffee aroma for all participants throughout the experiment. We also manipulated the context in which the participants were prompted to indicate any unusual stimuli and the explicitness of the prompts (5 levels of this variable: free response out of the room, response to a sensory modality specific prompt out of the room, free response in the room, response to a sensory modality specific prompt in the room, response to a stimulus  specific prompt in the room). If the critical stimulus is detected, the following prompts will be omitted.

- Subitizing task: The subitizing capacity threshold will be estimated using the curve-fitting procedure detailed by Leibovich-Raveh et al, 2018, applied to accuracy data as opposed to reaction times. Participants’ mean accuracy at each set size from 1 to 8 (averaged across all trials) will be fit with a sigmoid function with two parameters c1 and c2: f(x)=1/1+e-c1*(x-c2) using a non-linear error minimization algorithm. C1 and c2 correspond to the steepness of the curve and the value of the midpoint respectively. Subsequently, two lines will be fit to the sigmoid curve: one line with a slope of 0 and an intercept at x=0, and a second line which corresponds to the tangent at the inflection point of the sigmoid function. The point at which these lines intersects gives the upper bound of the subitizing range, i.e. the subitizing threshold.

- Inattentional blindness: Participants will indicate if they detected the critical stimulus, presented to the left or right of the display on the last trial of the subitizing task, by answering the following 3 questions following the inattentional blindness trial and the control trial (high and low load conditions):
1. Binary response: 'Did you ever notice anything appear next to the stimulus display? Press y for "yes", n for "no". You can correct your response by pressing the backspace key. Press ENTER to confirm you response. Please do not use uppercase letters or punctuation.'
2. Multiple choice (4 options): 'Where did it appear? (Guess if you are not sure.) 1 = above, 2 = below, 3 = right, 4 = left. You can correct your response by pressing the backspace key. Press ENTER to confirm you response. Please do not use uppercase letters or punctuation.'
3. Multiple choice (8 options): 'What appeared? (Guess if you are not sure.) 1 = %, 2 = &, 3 = #, 4 = @, 5 = ?, 6 = &;, 7 = *, 8 = $. You can correct your response by pressing the backspace key. Press ENTER to confirm your response. Please do not use uppercase letters or punctuation.'

- Inattentional deafness (gorilla task): Participants will answer the following questions.
Free response to the control question: 'What colour did the women choose? You can correct your response by pressing the backspace key. Press ENTER to confirm your response. Please do not use uppercase letters or punctuation.’
Free response to the question: 'Did you hear anything unusual (i.e. out of context) said by either the female or male speakers? If so, what? You can correct your response by pressing the backspace key. Press ENTER to confirm your response. Please do not use uppercase letters or punctuation.’ (attend to female voices condition)
Free response to the question: 'Did you hear anything unusual (i.e. out of context)? If so, what? You can correct your response by pressing the backspace key. Press ENTER to confirm your response. Please do not use uppercase letters or punctuation.’ This response is only collected if the response to question 2 does not contain the word "gorilla".  (attend to male voices condition)

- Inattentional deafness (clock): We will collect participants' responses to the following prompts and determine the prompt number at which the stimulus is detected. The questions will be asked outside of the room, then again inside. The script will be followed until the stimulus is detected or until the last question (5th prompt) is asked. Prompts outside of the room: 1st prompt (“Did you notice anything unusual in the room?  Consider all of your senses!”), 2nd prompt (“Did you notice any sounds in the room, if so what?”). Prompts in the room: 3rd prompt (“Do you notice anything unusual in the room?  Consider all of your senses!”), 4th prompt (“Do you notice any sounds in the room, if so what?”), 5th prompt (“Do you hear a ticking clock?”).
Participants will rate their aversion to the stimulus on a 5 point scale if the stimulus was detected (“Did the sound bother you?” 1=not at all, 5=a lot). This data is purely descriptive.

- Inattentional anosmia: We will collect participants' responses to the following prompts and determine the prompt number at which the stimulus is detected. The questions will be asked outside of the room, then again inside. The script will be followed until the stimulus is detected or until the last question (5th prompt) is asked. Prompts outside of the room: 1st prompt (“Did you notice anything unusual in the room?  Consider all of your senses!”), 2nd prompt (“Did you notice any smells in the room, if so what?”). Prompts outside of the room: 3rd prompt (“Do you notice anything unusual in the room?  Consider all of your senses!”), 4th prompt (“Do you notice any smells in the room, if so what?”), 5th prompt (“Do you smell coffee or chocolate?”).
Participants will rate their aversion to the stimulus on a 5 point scale if the stimulus was detected (“Did the smell bother you?” 1=not at all, 5=a lot). This data is purely descriptive.

- Subitizing task: Accuracy scores per condition (i.e. set size), will be determined by calculating the percentage of correct responses across all trials (excluding the practice blocks) for each set size. These scores will then be fitted as described above to a sigmoid function.

- Inattentional unawareness tasks: The number of detected stimuli (coded as detailed below) will be added in order to calculate a percentage score for each participant, corresponding to the number of detected stimuli relative to total number of presented critical stimuli (4).

-Within-subject associations:
We will use a Spearman's correlation to evaluate if there is an association between inattentional unawareness and subitizing capacity.

-Individual differences: 
Subitizing threshold: We will use multiple linear regression to determine if GSQ and AQ scores predict the subitizing threshold determined as specified above. In order to calculate the Bayes factor using the ratio of scales heuristic (Dienes, 2019), we will calculate Spearman's correlations between GSQ and the subitizing threshold, as well as between AQ and the subitizing threshold.

Inattentional unawareness score: We will use multiple linear regression to determine if GSQ and AQ scores predict the inattentional unawareness score calculated as specified above. In order to calculate the Bayes factor using the ratio of scales heuristic (Dienes, 2019), we will calculate Spearman's correlations between GSQ and the subitizing threshold, as well as between AQ and the subitizing threshold.

q20.value:
- Questionnaires: The raw scores of the two scales (AQ and GSQ) will be divided by the number of questions in order to get a raw unit in original rating units.

- Inattentional blindness: Responses to the three questions will be scored as follows:
Awareness: participants who are able to correctly identify both the shape and the location of the critical stimulus following a “Yes” awareness response following the inattentional blindness trial.
No awareness: all other response combinations following the inattentional blindness trial.

- Inattentional deafness (gorilla task): Responses to the three questions following the "attend to female" condition will be scored as follows:
Awareness: response to question 2 contains the word ‘gorilla’
No awareness: response to question 2 does not contain the word ‘gorilla’

- Inattentional deafness: Responses will be scored as follows:
Awareness: response to the 1st prompt or a spontaneous comment during the experiment contains one or more of the words ‘clock’, ‘watch’, and ‘ticking’.
No awareness: neither the response to the 1st prompt nor a spontaneous comment during the experiment contains any of the words ‘clock’, ‘watch’, and ‘ticking’.

-Inattentional anosmia: As our pilot data indicated that participants labelled the smell (when their attention was directed towards it) as either coffee or chocolate, both are considered as acceptable.
Awareness: response to the 1st prompt or a spontaneous comment during the experiment contains the words ‘coffee’ or ‘chocolate’.
No awareness: neither the response to the 1st prompt nor a spontaneous comment during the experiment contains the words ‘coffee’ or ‘chocolate’.

q21.value:
We will use frequentist and bayesian significance tests throughout.
For frequentist analyses, we will use the standard p = 0.05 criterion to determine if the corresponding independent variable is significantly associated with the dependent variable. In Bayesian analyses, we will use the standard Bayes factor (BF) criterion of ⅓ and 3 to reject and accept the hypothesis respectively. These BFs will be calculated using the ratio of scales heuristic (Dienes, 2019), in which the maximum regression slope M predicted by the theory tested is assumed to be the ratio of the lengths of the two scales being correlated.  This value is used to model H1 as a half-normal with SD = M/2.

q22.value:
- Subitizing task: As in previous research, responses for the set size of 9 will be excluded from the analysis because of “end effects” - participants tend to guess the maximum value when presented with large set sizes, which artificially inflates accuracy (Eayrs & Lavie, 2018). A participant will be excluded from this task if performance is at chance level in the lowest set size (set size of 1) taking the average accuracy across all trials, if they complete less than 95% of the trials overall, or if the RMSE of the fitted sigmoid curve is 1 SD below the group mean RMSE.

- Inattentional blindness: Participants will be excluded if the responses to the questions posed after the control trial are coded as "unaware" following the criteria detailed above, or if responses to any of the questions after the inattentional blindness or the control trial are missing.
 
- Inattentional deafness (gorilla task): Participants will be excluded if the responses to the questions posed in the control condition are coded as "unaware" following the criteria detailed above (after their attention has been directed explicitly to the male voices), if they respond incorrectly to the control question in the "attend to female voices" condition, which ensures their attention to the female voices, or if any responses are missing.

- Inattentional deafness: Participants will be excluded if they report unawareness of the critical stimulus in the control condition (after their attention has been directed explicitly to the ticking clock inside the room in the 5th prompt), or if any responses are missing from necessary prompts.

- Inattentional anosmia: Participants will be excluded if they report unawareness of the critical stimulus in the control condition (after their attention has been directed explicitly to the coffee/chocolate smell inside the room in the 5th prompt), or if any responses are missing from necessary prompts.

q23.value: If a participant is excluded from the subitizing task due to poor accuracy in the set size of 1 or less than 90% submitted responses, the data pertaining to all other tasks will be excluded from the analysis as well, as this makes the participant's engagement, and hence the effectiveness of the attention/load manipulations doubtful. If a participant is excluded from more than one of the inattentional unawareness tasks, the participant will be excluded from all of the other inattentional unawareness tasks but not the subitizing task. In all other cases, a participant's exclusion from a task will not affect the inclusion of their data in any other task.

q24.value: As we assume the phenomenon of inattentional unawareness to be at least partially multimodal  (e.g. Martens et al, 2010 found a correlation of 0.37 between visual attentional blink and performance on the auditory gorilla task), we expect the likelihood to detect stimuli to be correlated across sensory modalities, i.e. that people who detect one stimulus are more likely to detect all others. However, there are additional factors which should be taken into account; e.g., olfactory selective attention is particularly poor (Sela & Sobel, 2010), and the critical stimuli differ on the scale of their presentation time (ambient/continuous throughout the experiment vs restricted to a specific time window in a computer-based task). As these interactions complicates the articulation of specific predictions, the association between the unawareness measures will be explored using chi square tests and/or factor analysis, and these results will be potentially confirmed in future studies.

This study found a medium effect size (Cohen’s d of 0.5) of awareness on GSQ, which we used as our prior estimate - this would correspond to a Cohen’s f of 0.25  and hence a Cohen’s f^2 of 0.0625 (a medium effect size for multiple regression and F tests). A power analysis revealed that a sample size of n=129 should be sufficient to detect an effect size of this magnitude with a power of .8, assuming a significance level of .05 when performing multiple linear regression or correlation (two-tailed test).
For the association between inattentional unawareness and AQ, we relied on data comparing neurotypical participants to participants diagnosed with autism spectrum conditions (Remington et al, 2012; Remington & Fairnie, 2018). As the effect size calculated based on the reported results in high-load conditions is high in the visual modality (Cohen’s d of 0.88), and medium in the auditory modality (Cohen’s d of 0.4), we based our power analysis calculation on the smaller effect size. A power analysis revealed that a sample size of  n=199 should be sufficient to detect an effect size of this magnitude with a power of .8, assuming a significance level of .05 when performing multiple linear regression or correlation (two-tailed test).

- Across subjects: association between subitizing capacity and GSQ/AQ
Studies comparing neurotypical individuals and individuals with autism spectrum conditions (ASC) report either small negative effects or no effect of ASCs on subitizing capacity (Jarrold & Russell, 1997; Gagnon et al, 2004; O’Hearn et al, 2013; O’Hearn et al, 2015). However, it should be noted that a number of these studies include children and all focus on clinically diagnosed ASCs. Furthermore, Eayrs & Lavie, 2018, show that subitizing predicted change detection rates and the performance of both tasks were underpinned by a single factor according to their confirmatory factor analysis, and there is evidence of reduced susceptibility to change blindness in autism (e.g. Swettenham et al, 2014; Smith & Milne, 2009). Given the conflicting accounts for the relationship of subitizing and AQ, we do not have a prediction regarding the effect of AQ on the subitizing threshold (this part of the analysis could therefore be considered exploratory, but is detailed here for legibility.) 
In the absence of empirical evidence on any association between the GSQ and subitizing, we assume similar effect sizes for the association between subitizing capacity and GSQ as we did for the association between inattentional unawareness and GSQ.
registration_responses.q15:
As the main area of interest is the association of the GSQ with the performance on these behavioral tasks, we will collect a minimum of 150 complete data sets (i.e. participants who complete all 5 of the tasks and both questionnaires),  and a maximum of 200 complete data sets, with an additional cap on the total number of participants of 220, irrespective of missing or excluded data.
We will additionally begin calculating BFs after every additional 20 participants once we reach the minimum sample size. If all BFs on the following tests are either below or above the threshold of ⅓ or 3, as specified above, we will stop data collection: correlation between the subitizing capacity and the percentage of detected stimuli, correlation between GSQ and the subitizing capacity, correlation between GSQ and the percentage of detected stimuli, correlation between AQ and the percentage of detected stimuli.
registration_responses.q20:
- Questionnaires: The raw scores of the two scales (AQ and GSQ) will be divided by the number of questions in order to get a raw unit in original rating units.

- Inattentional blindness: Responses to the three questions will be scored as follows:
Awareness: participants who are able to correctly identify both the shape and the location of the critical stimulus following a “Yes” awareness response following the inattentional blindness trial.
No awareness: all other response combinations following the inattentional blindness trial.

- Inattentional deafness (gorilla task): Responses to the three questions following the "attend to female" condition will be scored as follows:
Awareness: response to question 2 contains the word ‘gorilla’
No awareness: response to question 2 does not contain the word ‘gorilla’

- Inattentional deafness: Responses will be scored as follows:
Awareness: response to the 1st prompt or a spontaneous comment during the experiment contains one or more of the words ‘clock’, ‘watch’, and ‘ticking’.
No awareness: neither the response to the 1st prompt nor a spontaneous comment during the experiment contains any of the words ‘clock’, ‘watch’, and ‘ticking’.

-Inattentional anosmia: As our pilot data indicated that participants labelled the smell (when their attention was directed towards it) as either coffee or chocolate, both are considered as acceptable.
Awareness: response to the 1st prompt or a spontaneous comment during the experiment contains the words ‘coffee’ or ‘chocolate’.
No awareness: neither the response to the 1st prompt nor a spontaneous comment during the experiment contains the words ‘coffee’ or ‘chocolate’.
registration_responses.q21:
We will use frequentist and bayesian significance tests throughout.
For frequentist analyses, we will use the standard p = 0.05 criterion to determine if the corresponding independent variable is significantly associated with the dependent variable. In Bayesian analyses, we will use the standard Bayes factor (BF) criterion of ⅓ and 3 to reject and accept the hypothesis respectively. These BFs will be calculated using the ratio of scales heuristic (Dienes, 2019), in which the maximum regression slope M predicted by the theory tested is assumed to be the ratio of the lengths of the two scales being correlated.  This value is used to model H1 as a half-normal with SD = M/2.
registration_responses.q22:
- Subitizing task: As in previous research, responses for the set size of 9 will be excluded from the analysis because of “end effects” - participants tend to guess the maximum value when presented with large set sizes, which artificially inflates accuracy (Eayrs & Lavie, 2018). A participant will be excluded from this task if performance is at chance level in the lowest set size (set size of 1) taking the average accuracy across all trials, if they complete less than 95% of the trials overall, or if the RMSE of the fitted sigmoid curve is 1 SD below the group mean RMSE.

- Inattentional blindness: Participants will be excluded if the responses to the questions posed after the control trial are coded as "unaware" following the criteria detailed above, or if responses to any of the questions after the inattentional blindness or the control trial are missing.
 
- Inattentional deafness (gorilla task): Participants will be excluded if the responses to the questions posed in the control condition are coded as "unaware" following the criteria detailed above (after their attention has been directed explicitly to the male voices), if they respond incorrectly to the control question in the "attend to female voices" condition, which ensures their attention to the female voices, or if any responses are missing.

- Inattentional deafness: Participants will be excluded if they report unawareness of the critical stimulus in the control condition (after their attention has been directed explicitly to the ticking clock inside the room in the 5th prompt), or if any responses are missing from necessary prompts.

- Inattentional anosmia: Participants will be excluded if they report unawareness of the critical stimulus in the control condition (after their attention has been directed explicitly to the coffee/chocolate smell inside the room in the 5th prompt), or if any responses are missing from necessary prompts.
registration_responses.q23: If a participant is excluded from the subitizing task due to poor accuracy in the set size of 1 or less than 90% submitted responses, the data pertaining to all other tasks will be excluded from the analysis as well, as this makes the participant's engagement, and hence the effectiveness of the attention/load manipulations doubtful. If a participant is excluded from more than one of the inattentional unawareness tasks, the participant will be excluded from all of the other inattentional unawareness tasks but not the subitizing task. In all other cases, a participant's exclusion from a task will not affect the inclusion of their data in any other task.
registration_responses.q24: As we assume the phenomenon of inattentional unawareness to be at least partially multimodal  (e.g. Martens et al, 2010 found a correlation of 0.37 between visual attentional blink and performance on the auditory gorilla task), we expect the likelihood to detect stimuli to be correlated across sensory modalities, i.e. that people who detect one stimulus are more likely to detect all others. However, there are additional factors which should be taken into account; e.g., olfactory selective attention is particularly poor (Sela & Sobel, 2010), and the critical stimuli differ on the scale of their presentation time (ambient/continuous throughout the experiment vs restricted to a specific time window in a computer-based task). As these interactions complicates the articulation of specific predictions, the association between the unawareness measures will be explored using chi square tests and/or factor analysis, and these results will be potentially confirmed in future studies.
registration_responses.q8.question: Mixed design study (within-subject as well as between-subjects comparisons) in a study comprising 5 behavioral experiments and 2 questionnaires. The order of the two computer-based behavioral experiments will be counterbalanced by generating a look-up table in advance, which will assign a random order to each participant number. No further counterbalancing of the order will be possible due to the nature of the experiments: unattended auditory and olfactory stimuli will be presented throughout the testing session, and the critical stimulus in the inattentional blindness experiment will be presented at the end of the subitizing experiment to avoid any interference with the subitizing task.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be recruited through advertisements at the University of Sussex. They will be at least 18 years old and will report normal or corrected-to-normal vision and hearing. As compensation for their time we will conduct a prize draw, with three prizes of £25.  If the sample size is not reached at the end of the student testing period, we will offer compensation at the rate of £8 or 4 credits per hour.
registration_responses.q16.question:
- Subitizing task: We manipulated the set size, i.e. number of squares on the display. The 9 levels of this variable are set sizes from 1 to 9.

- Inattentional blindness: We manipulated the location of the critical stimulus on the screen. The two levels of this variable are left and right. We also manipulated the load/attention. The two levels of this variable are a high load condition with no warning regarding the critical stimulus, and a low load condition with an instruction to not perform the task and instead look for any additional stimuli on the screen.

- Inattentional deafness (gorilla task): We manipulated load/attention while playing an identical recording of an auditory scene with an auditory critical stimulus (Dalton & Fraenkel, 2012) . The two levels of this variable are "attend to female voices" and "attend to male voices". If the critical stimulus is detected in the "attend to female voices" condition, the second condition will be omitted.

- Inattentional deafness: We manipulated the auditory environment by playing the sound of a ticking clock at a constant intensity for all participants throughout the experiment. We also manipulated the context in which the participants were prompted to indicate any unusual stimuli and the explicitness of the prompts (5 levels of this variable: free response out of the room, response to a sensory modality specific prompt out of the room, free response in the room, response to a sensory modality specific prompt in the room, response to a stimulus  specific prompt in the room).  If the critical stimulus is detected, the following prompts will be omitted.

- Inattentional anosmia: We manipulated the olfactory environment by keeping coffee fragrance oil in the room, ensuring similar intensity of a coffee aroma for all participants throughout the experiment. We also manipulated the context in which the participants were prompted to indicate any unusual stimuli and the explicitness of the prompts (5 levels of this variable: free response out of the room, response to a sensory modality specific prompt out of the room, free response in the room, response to a sensory modality specific prompt in the room, response to a stimulus  specific prompt in the room). If the critical stimulus is detected, the following prompts will be omitted.
registration_responses.q17.question:
- Subitizing task: The subitizing capacity threshold will be estimated using the curve-fitting procedure detailed by Leibovich-Raveh et al, 2018, applied to accuracy data as opposed to reaction times. Participants’ mean accuracy at each set size from 1 to 8 (averaged across all trials) will be fit with a sigmoid function with two parameters c1 and c2: f(x)=1/1+e-c1*(x-c2) using a non-linear error minimization algorithm. C1 and c2 correspond to the steepness of the curve and the value of the midpoint respectively. Subsequently, two lines will be fit to the sigmoid curve: one line with a slope of 0 and an intercept at x=0, and a second line which corresponds to the tangent at the inflection point of the sigmoid function. The point at which these lines intersects gives the upper bound of the subitizing range, i.e. the subitizing threshold.

- Inattentional blindness: Participants will indicate if they detected the critical stimulus, presented to the left or right of the display on the last trial of the subitizing task, by answering the following 3 questions following the inattentional blindness trial and the control trial (high and low load conditions):
1. Binary response: 'Did you ever notice anything appear next to the stimulus display? Press y for "yes", n for "no". You can correct your response by pressing the backspace key. Press ENTER to confirm you response. Please do not use uppercase letters or punctuation.'
2. Multiple choice (4 options): 'Where did it appear? (Guess if you are not sure.) 1 = above, 2 = below, 3 = right, 4 = left. You can correct your response by pressing the backspace key. Press ENTER to confirm you response. Please do not use uppercase letters or punctuation.'
3. Multiple choice (8 options): 'What appeared? (Guess if you are not sure.) 1 = %, 2 = &, 3 = #, 4 = @, 5 = ?, 6 = &;, 7 = *, 8 = $. You can correct your response by pressing the backspace key. Press ENTER to confirm your response. Please do not use uppercase letters or punctuation.'

- Inattentional deafness (gorilla task): Participants will answer the following questions.
Free response to the control question: 'What colour did the women choose? You can correct your response by pressing the backspace key. Press ENTER to confirm your response. Please do not use uppercase letters or punctuation.’
Free response to the question: 'Did you hear anything unusual (i.e. out of context) said by either the female or male speakers? If so, what? You can correct your response by pressing the backspace key. Press ENTER to confirm your response. Please do not use uppercase letters or punctuation.’ (attend to female voices condition)
Free response to the question: 'Did you hear anything unusual (i.e. out of context)? If so, what? You can correct your response by pressing the backspace key. Press ENTER to confirm your response. Please do not use uppercase letters or punctuation.’ This response is only collected if the response to question 2 does not contain the word "gorilla".  (attend to male voices condition)

- Inattentional deafness (clock): We will collect participants' responses to the following prompts and determine the prompt number at which the stimulus is detected. The questions will be asked outside of the room, then again inside. The script will be followed until the stimulus is detected or until the last question (5th prompt) is asked. Prompts outside of the room: 1st prompt (“Did you notice anything unusual in the room?  Consider all of your senses!”), 2nd prompt (“Did you notice any sounds in the room, if so what?”). Prompts in the room: 3rd prompt (“Do you notice anything unusual in the room?  Consider all of your senses!”), 4th prompt (“Do you notice any sounds in the room, if so what?”), 5th prompt (“Do you hear a ticking clock?”).
Participants will rate their aversion to the stimulus on a 5 point scale if the stimulus was detected (“Did the sound bother you?” 1=not at all, 5=a lot). This data is purely descriptive.

- Inattentional anosmia: We will collect participants' responses to the following prompts and determine the prompt number at which the stimulus is detected. The questions will be asked outside of the room, then again inside. The script will be followed until the stimulus is detected or until the last question (5th prompt) is asked. Prompts outside of the room: 1st prompt (“Did you notice anything unusual in the room?  Consider all of your senses!”), 2nd prompt (“Did you notice any smells in the room, if so what?”). Prompts outside of the room: 3rd prompt (“Do you notice anything unusual in the room?  Consider all of your senses!”), 4th prompt (“Do you notice any smells in the room, if so what?”), 5th prompt (“Do you smell coffee or chocolate?”).
Participants will rate their aversion to the stimulus on a 5 point scale if the stimulus was detected (“Did the smell bother you?” 1=not at all, 5=a lot). This data is purely descriptive.
registration_responses.q18.question:
- Subitizing task: Accuracy scores per condition (i.e. set size), will be determined by calculating the percentage of correct responses across all trials (excluding the practice blocks) for each set size. These scores will then be fitted as described above to a sigmoid function.

- Inattentional unawareness tasks: The number of detected stimuli (coded as detailed below) will be added in order to calculate a percentage score for each participant, corresponding to the number of detected stimuli relative to total number of presented critical stimuli (4).
registration_responses.q19.question:
-Within-subject associations:
We will use a Spearman's correlation to evaluate if there is an association between inattentional unawareness and subitizing capacity.

-Individual differences: 
Subitizing threshold: We will use multiple linear regression to determine if GSQ and AQ scores predict the subitizing threshold determined as specified above. In order to calculate the Bayes factor using the ratio of scales heuristic (Dienes, 2019), we will calculate Spearman's correlations between GSQ and the subitizing threshold, as well as between AQ and the subitizing threshold.

Inattentional unawareness score: We will use multiple linear regression to determine if GSQ and AQ scores predict the inattentional unawareness score calculated as specified above. In order to calculate the Bayes factor using the ratio of scales heuristic (Dienes, 2019), we will calculate Spearman's correlations between GSQ and the subitizing threshold, as well as between AQ and the subitizing threshold.

summary.value:
This document represents the registration of the WP5 component (The Focus Group Study) of the project: 'Standard Operating Procedures for Research Integrity' (SOPs4RI) on 13 February 2020.

The research objectives, empirical questions, methodology, ethical approval, etc. are presented in the following documentation:

1) WP5 description 

2) Protocol for Focus Group Study 

The aim of the focus group study is to provide discipline-specific knowledge on SOPs and guidelines related to research integrity. The focus group study will consist of 32 focus group interviews with researchers from the humanities, social science, natural science, and medical science together with relevant stakeholders. 16 focus groups will involve researches from the different main fields of research, and 16 groups will comprise researchers as well as relevant stakeholders.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: In addition to the study run in osf.io/wc2f6, we will additionally measure justice sensitivity to prepare future work using the identical task. The hypothesis is that other-regarding justice sensitivity positively correlates with sustainable decision making.

sample.value: The sample size is 400 HITS that are created using Amazon Mechanical Turk. The sample size has been decided based on budgetary constraints.

analyses.value: We will run a logistic/probit regression with the choice to enroll in a study with hypothetical rather than real financial and environmental consequences as the dependent variable and trait self-control, environmental attitudes (measured by NEP, Dunlap et al.) and their interaction as independent variables.

outliers.value: We will exclude participants who fail to correctly answer the control question.

dependent.value: The key dependent variable is the endogenous choice whether participants self-select into a decision task (identical to osf.io/wc2f6) that pitches financial gains and environmental costs against each other.

conditions.value: This is a correlational study, but participants answer 25 trials of a decision conflict as in osf.io/wc2f6.

hypothesis.value: The main research question is whether people high in trait self-control, measured by the 13-item BSCS (Tangney et al., 2004), avoid temptations by not self-selecting into situations that require inhibition ability.

q4.value:
the link between membership to one or several stigmatized categories and the sensitivity to discrimination;

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A 2 (participants’ age: young vs old) x 2 (participants’ gender: male vs. female) x 2 (employment status: employed vs. unemployed) between-subject factorial design was used

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value: Participants were contacted by email, either through web forums or through associations supporting the seniors back to work. They all volunteered to participate in the study

q13.value: The sample included 422 participants from Western France

question.value: A 2 (participants’ age: young vs old) x 2 (participants’ gender: male vs. female) x 2 (employment status: employed vs. unemployed) between-subject factorial design was used

- Perceived age discrimination was measured using a 4-item scale adapted from Redman and Snape’s (2006) measure of perceived discrimination among older individuals (e.g., “My age prevents me from getting jobs for which I think I am qualified”). 
- Work/job self-esteem (r ̅ =.404) was measured using 4 items drawn from the Lagacé and Tougas adaptation (2006) of the Rosenberg (1965) 10-item self-esteem scale (e.g., “At work, and in general, I am satisfied with what I am”). 
- Affective Commitment  was measured using 3 items drawn from Allen and Meyer (1990) 8-item subscale measuring the affective commitment (e.g., “This organization has a great deal of personal meaning for me”). 
- Continuance commitment  was measured using 3 items drawn from Allen and Meyer’s (1990) 8-item subscale measuring the continuance commitment (e.g., “It would be very hard for me to leave my organization right now, even if I wanted to”). 
- Retirement intention  was measured using 2 items drawn from a 4-item scale adapted from Snape and Redman’s (2003a) measure of retirement intention among older adults (e.g., “I would like to retire in the near future”). 
- Age-group identificationwas measured using the 5-item scale of Garstka et al. (2004) measure of age-group identification among younger and older adults (e.g., “I like being a member of my age-group”).

attributes.title: What stops you from killing yourself? Examining Reddit users reasons for not making a suicide attempt
attributes.description: Suicide is a growing health problem, despite our best efforts to understand the factors the may lead to the emergence of suicidal thoughts and behaviours, and to develop effective intervention and prevention strategies. One reason to explain the limited effectiveness of current suicide policies may be that we still understand little about the reasons that stop people from killing themselves. Therefore, in contrast to classical bottom-up approaches that seek to determine the factors that may lead to, and contribute to, suicidality, we intend to investigate the reasons that Reddit users have for not engaging in suicidal behaviours. Additionally, we intend to look at which comments receive more upvotes / comments of support.

q1.value: "What stops you from killing yourself?" Reasons that Reddit users have from not making a suicide attempt

q2.value: Andre Mason, Benjamin Riordan, Scarf Damian, Kenny Jang

q3.value: Suicide is a growing health problem, despite our best efforts to understand the factors the may lead to the emergence of suicidal thoughts and behaviours, and to develop effective intervention and prevention strategies. One reason to explain the limited effectiveness of current suicide policies may be that we still understand little about the reasons that stop people from killing themselves. Therefore, in contrast to classical bottom-up approaches that seek to determine the factors that may lead to, and contribute to, suicidality, we intend to investigate the reasons that Reddit users have for not engaging in suicidal behaviours. Additionally, we intend to look at which comments receive more upvotes / comments of support.

q4.value: Based on theories consistent with an ideation-to-action framework (e.g. Klonsky's Three Step Theory), we expect that fear of pain/death and a sense of connectedness would be commonly cited as a reason for users not to kill themselves.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We intend to use R to interact with Reddit's API to extract comments under posts on the subreddit /r/AskReddit where Redditors are asked to report  reasons that stop them from killing themselves.

data.name: Reddit - What is stoppping you from killing yourself - Threads to extract.xlsx

extra.selectedFileName: Reddit - What is stoppping you from killing yourself - Threads to extract.xlsx

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: We have extracted a collection of relevant posts from Reddit and merged them into a file in preparation for analyses. Additionally, two members of the study's team have had a preliminary look at 100 randomly selected posts to ensure there is enough content for analysis and to create a coding book to be used in later analyses.

question.value: Using the search term “killing yourself”, we have extracted posts from Reddit related to reasons that people believe stop themselves from kill themselves using the R package RedditExtractoR (Rivera, 2019) .

q14.value: We collected all relevant posts found using the search term "killing yourself"

question.value: We have two outcomes. Firstly, the reasons that users give for not killing themselves and secondly, the number of upvotes/comments of support.

We will use thematic analyses to generate summaries of themes and concepts from coded data. Specifically, two authors have reviewed 100 randomly selected posts and discussed the overlap and points of departure to create a master coding book. Each author of the study will be asked to code a given number of posts and between all authors, the complete set of posts will be coded. Each post will be coded by at least two authors and level of agreement will be calculated using Cohen's kappa.

We will use linear modelling to test whether upvotes can be predicted as a function of post content, accounting for random effects between posts and controlling for length of post and whether or not the post is considered a 'top comment'

registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11: We have extracted a collection of relevant posts from Reddit and merged them into a file in preparation for analyses. Additionally, two members of the study's team have had a preliminary look at 100 randomly selected posts to ensure there is enough content for analysis and to create a coding book to be used in later analyses.
registration_responses.q14: We collected all relevant posts found using the search term "killing yourself"
registration_responses.q8.question: We intend to use R to interact with Reddit's API to extract comments under posts on the subreddit /r/AskReddit where Redditors are asked to report  reasons that stop them from killing themselves.

q8.uploader.file_name: Reddit - What is stoppping you from killing yourself - Threads to extract.xlsx

registration_responses.q12.question: Using the search term “killing yourself”, we have extracted posts from Reddit related to reasons that people believe stop themselves from kill themselves using the R package RedditExtractoR (Rivera, 2019) .
registration_responses.q17.question: We have two outcomes. Firstly, the reasons that users give for not killing themselves and secondly, the number of upvotes/comments of support.
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will use thematic analyses to generate summaries of themes and concepts from coded data. Specifically, two authors have reviewed 100 randomly selected posts and discussed the overlap and points of departure to create a master coding book. Each author of the study will be asked to code a given number of posts and between all authors, the complete set of posts will be coded. Each post will be coded by at least two authors and level of agreement will be calculated using Cohen's kappa.

We will use linear modelling to test whether upvotes can be predicted as a function of post content, accounting for random effects between posts and controlling for length of post and whether or not the post is considered a 'top comment'

attributes.title: The influence of the belief of a social interaction on the perception of space
attributes.description:
Pre-registration of experiment on the influence of the belief of a social interaction on the perception of space conducted in February 2020

Human visual perception is not a mere photography of physical stimuli, but rather undergoes several alterations, as demonstrated by visual illusions. Since perception has been shown as a form of unconscious inference where our experience can influence what we perceive, an open question in the research on perceptual inference is whether and how we employ it when we interact with other social agents. From this basis, this experiment aims to understand whether the belief of interacting with a partner affects the inference of our prior experience on perception of space given by the perceptual mechanism of the Central Tendency Effect.

attributes.title: Psychosocial Effects of Receiving Polygenic Risk Information Related to Diabetes and Coronary Artery Disease

q1.value: Psychosocial Effects of Receiving Polygenic Risk Information Related to Diabetes and Coronary Artery Disease

q3.value:
A. To explore differences in self-efficacy, risk assessment, intentions to change health behavior and emotional reactions that take place when participants receive genomic and traditional risk information concerning diabetes type 2 and coronary artery disease, in comparison to a situation where participants receive only traditional risk information concerning the same diseases.

B. To investigate how the aforementioned groups differ concerning subsequent health behavior.

q4.value:
A.1 We will investigate (non-directional) if immediately after receiving the risk information the group receiving genomic + traditional will a) perceive that they are in higher risk of getting the two diseases, b) experience more worry, c) intent to exercise more d) intent to eat more vegetables and fruits e) are more likely to sought medical help for the conditions f) report lower self-efficacy concerning the two diseases g) experience different positive/negative emotions concerning the test results.


B.1 We will investigate (non-directional) if 3 months after receiving the risk information the group receiving genomic + traditional will report a) increased physical activity b) increased consumption of vegetables or berries c) more healthy diet d) decreased alcohol consumption e) decreased smoking f) decreased weight and/or intention to lose weight.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The design involves 3 measurement points. One right before, one immediately after, and one 3 months after the risk information is received. Between-group comparisons (experiment and active control) will be made in measurement points 2 and 3.

q9.value: Individual participants will be randomized to approximately equal-size groups.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data collection is still in process. No formal analyses have been done.

question.value: The project is a continuation of FinHealth 2017 Study involving thousands of Finns from around the country. 3449 out of 6189 (55%) invited participants of FinHealth have taken part in the current study (i.e., given their consent).

q13.value: 3449 participants have given their consent to take part in the study.

question.value: The manipulated variable is whether participants receive polygenic + traditional risk information or only traditional risk information concerning diabetes type 2 and coronary artery disease.

Measurement point 1:

-Perceived risk for CAD/D2 (1 item)
-Self-efficacy related to CAD/D2 (1 item)
-Worry related to CAD/D2 risk (1 item)
-General willingness to take risks (1 item)
-Willingness to give up something useful to gain more profit in the future (1 item)



Measurement point 2:

-Perceived risk for CAD/D2 (1 item)
-Self-efficacy related to CAD/D2 (1 item)
-Worry related to traditional CAD/D2 risk (1 item)
-Worry related to polygenic CAD/D2 risk (1 item)
-8 items measuring attitudes related to the risk profile participants received
-Intention to increase physical activity (1 item)
-Intention to increase consumption of vegetables/fruits (1 item)
-Have participants sought medical attention for the condition / or intends to do so (1 item)
-8 items from MICRA (Cella et al. 2002)
-Outcome expectations related to physical activity and D2 (1 item)
-Outcome expectations related to physical activity and CAD (1 item)
-Outcome expectations related to diet and D2 (1 item)
-Outcome expectations related to diet and CAD (1 item)
-Self-reported consumption of vegetables/fruits (2 items)
-6 items related to food choices
-Smoking status (1 item)
-Last time participant smoked (1 item)
-Willingness to quit smoking (1 item)
-Self-reported alcohol consumption (2 items)
-Self-reported physical activity (4 items)
-Self-reported weight (kg) (1 item)
-How many times participant has tried to diet (1 item)
-Best dieting result (kg) (1 item)
-Is participant dieting now (1 item)
-Warwick-Edinburgh Mental Well-being Scale (14 items; Tennant et al. 2007)



Measurement point 3

-Self-reported consumption of vegetables/fruits (2 items)
-6 items related to food choices
-Smoking status (1 item)
-Last time participant smoked (1 item)
-Willingness to quit smoking (1 item)
-Self-reported alcohol consumption (2 items)
-Self-reported physical activity (4 items)
-Self-reported weight (kg) (1 item)
-How many times participant has tried to diet (1 item)
-Best dieting result (kg) (1 item)
-Is participant dieting now (1 item)
-Have participants sought medical attention for the condition / or intends to do so (1 item)

Group differences will be tested with ANCOVA, where the baseline is added as a covariate (baseline for health behavior is gained from measurement point 2). When no baseline is available (i.e., with items that measure direct reaction to the test result), ANOVA will be utilized.

q24.value: Analyses outside group differences in health behavior and perceived risk/worry/self-efficacy will be exploratory.
